Security is critical in the change management process. Change management is a key part of compliance certifications in a majority of organizations, and it is necessary to prove that the process cannot be bypassed or taken advantage of.
 
It is recommended that only change managers who own the process and are responsible for it can alter information on a change request once it is submitted for approval. In addition, changes can only be updated at acceptable times and by users who own or are responsible for the change, for example, the requester, assignment group member, and assignee. Other users allowed to raise changes do not have access to update changes other than their own.
 
When approvals are requested, only those people who have been identified as approvers can take action on the change request.

The definition of a user directly associated with a change includes users in the Requested by, Opened by, or Assigned to fields, or a member of the assignment group.

Where Recommendation
 Change request Type field is Normal or Emergency and State field is New or Assess Any user directly associated with the change can edit all fields that are not read-only.
 Change request Type field is Normal or Emergency and State field is anything except Closed or Canceled The change_manager role can edit all fields that are not read-only.
 Change request Type field is Normal or Emergency and State field is New or Assess Any user directly associated with the change can edit all related lists.
 Change request Type field is Normal or Emergency and State field is  anything except Closed or Canceled The change_manager role can edit all related lists.
 Change task State field is New, In Progress or On Hold Any user directly associated with the change or change task, or who has the change_manager role, can edit all fields that are not read-only. 

 

To configure security for change requests based on these recommendations:

  1. Update Request Approval, Schedule, Implement, Review, Close, Cancel Change UI actions so that any user directly associated with the change can progress the change request through the life cycle.
  2. On the Change Tasks related list, open List Control to clear the Omit New button and add Omit new condition so that any user directly associated with the change can edit the related list at certain states.
  3. Setup up access control rules (ACLs) to apply role-based security:
    • Any user directly associated with the change can edit all fields that are not read-only at certain states, for example, New or Assess.
    • Any itil user can update work notes, comments, and work notes list on all change requests.
    • Only admin can delete approval records and group approval records.
